articles.description: President Donald Trump is lashing out at his own supporters as he tries to clamp down on criticism over his administration’s handling of much-hyped records in Jeffrey Epstein’s sex trafficking investigation. He's referring in a social media post Wednesday to what he calls “their new SCAM” and “the Jeffrey Epstein Hoax.” The Republican president says his “PAST supporters have bought” into it “hook, line, and sinker.” The Justice Department and the FBI say Epstein didn't maintain a “client list” and that no more files related to the investigation would be made public despite promises from Attorney General Pam Bondi that had raised the expectations of conservative influencers and conspiracy theorists.
articles.title: Trump slams his own supporters for criticizing handling of Epstein case

articles.description: President Donald Trump says he's “highly unlikely” to fire Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. His public statement Wednesday came less than 24 hours after suggesting in a private meeting that he was leaning in favor of dismissing Powell. Trump confirmed to reporters that in a White House meeting Tuesday night with about a dozen House Republicans, he'd discussed the “concept” of dismissing Powell. The Fed chair has long been a target because of his refusal to lower interest rates as Trump wants. Trump's team recently has accused Powell of mismanaging a $2.5 billion renovation project at the Fed. Trump said Wednesday he's “highly unlikely” to dismiss Powell — ”unless he has to leave for fraud.”
articles.title: Trump says he's 'highly unlikely' to fire Fed's Powel

articles.description: A key governing partner of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says it is quitting the government, leaving him with a minority in parliament. The Shas ultra-Orthodox party said Wednesday it was leaving over disagreements surrounding a proposed law meant to grant wide military draft exemptions to its constituents. A second ultra-Orthodox party quit earlier this week over the same issue. Shas said it wouldn’t work to undermine the coalition once outside it and could vote with it on some laws. It also wouldn’t support its collapse.
articles.title: A key coalition partner of Netanyahu is quitting, leaving him with minority in Israeli parliament

articles.description: An American aid organization in Gaza says 20 Palestinians were killed at a distribution site in Khan Younis. The Gaza Humanitarian Fund said 19 died in a stampede, and one was fatally stabbed on Wednesday. The group accuses Hamas of spreading panic but provides no evidence. The United Nations reports 875 Palestinians have died near aid sites since May. Meanwhile, hospital officials say Israeli strikes killed 41 others, including 11 children. Israel claims its strikes target Hamas infrastructure, accusing the group of hiding among civilians. Gaza faces a severe humanitarian crisis, with over 2 million residents struggling amid ongoing conflict and blockades.
articles.title: Israel-backed aid organization in Gaza says 20 killed at distribution site, mostly in stampede

articles.description: A bill to cancel about $9 billion in foreign aid and public broadcasting spending is nearing passage in the Senate. It's an action that would have a tiny impact on the nation’s debt but could have major ramifications for future spending fights in Congress. The legislation would claw back nearly $1.1 billion from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and about $8 billion in foreign aid spending that Republicans describe as wasteful. Senate passage of the spending cuts would send the bill back to the House for final approval. Trump must sign the bill into law by midnight Friday for the cuts to take effect.
articles.title: Trump bid to claw back $9 billion nears Senate vote

articles.description: A federal judge in Tennessee could rule on whether to release Kilmar Abrego Garcia from jail as he awaits trial on human smuggling charges. A decision to free the Maryland construction worker could allow President Donald Trump's administration to try to deport him for a second time. A hearing to review the matter is scheduled for Wednesday in Nashville. Abrego Garcia became a flashpoint over the Republican administration’s immigration policies when he was wrongfully deported to his native El Salvador in March. The U.S. returned Abrego Garcia last month to face the federal smuggling charges. Abrego Garcia’s lawyers say the case is preposterous.
articles.title: Kilmar Abrego Garcia faces hearing on Tennessee jail release

articles.description: The United States has deported five immigrants from Vietnam, Jamaica, Cuba, Yemen and Laos to Eswatini, a small country in southern Africa where the king still holds absolute power. Eswatini says it is holding the men in correctional facilities until they can be sent back to their home countries. Eswatini is one of a handful of countries in the world that are still absolute monarchies, and the only one in Africa. That means the king has absolute power over government and is not just a figurehead or a ceremonial position. The country was previously known as Swaziland but changed to Eswatini in 2018.
articles.title: What to know about the African kingdom of Eswatini where the US sent 5 deportees

articles.description: Authorities say three current or former Louisiana police chiefs have been arrested following a federal investigation into an alleged scheme that involved false police reports being sold to immigrants lacking permanent legal status and used to try to secure a visa. U.S. Attorney Alexander C. Van Hook said at a news conference Wednesday that the forged police reports would indicate that the immigrant was a victim of a crime. He said the police officials were paid $5,000 for each name they provided falsified reports for, and that there were hundreds of names. He and other officials said the case does not mean the police chiefs' departments are corrupt.
articles.title: Feds charge 5 in Louisiana, including 3 current or ex-police chiefs, over alleged visa fraud scheme

articles.description: Two university hospitals are pioneering new ways to expand access to the lifesaving heart transplants for adults and babies. They aim to overcome some barriers to retrieving hearts donated after circulatory death, when the heart stops beating after withdrawal of life support. Surgeons at Duke and Vanderbilt universities say they've separately devised some simpler approaches. In the New England Journal of Medicine, they describe small but early successes, transplanting an infant at Duke and three men at Vanderbilt. These are the kinds of transplantable hearts that too often aren’t retrieved depending on how would-be organ donors die.
articles.title: DCD heart transplants: Two hospitals try new ways to use more donated organs

articles.description: Researchers report that eight healthy babies were born with the help of an experimental technique that uses DNA from three people to help mothers avoid passing rare diseases to their children. Dangerous mutations in the cell’s mitochondria can cause a range of diseases, some causing major organ failure and death. Researchers have been developing a technique that takes genetic material from the mother’s egg or embryo, which is then transferred into a donor egg or embryo that has healthy mitochondria but the rest of its key DNA removed. Scientists described their findings in the New England Journal of Medicine on Wednesday.
articles.title: Eight healthy babies were born with DNA from three people in an effort to prevent rare diseases
